questionnaire.description: This coach for micro and small businesses outlines some of the first steps in cybersecurity for your company.

question.introduction: First Steps in Cybersecurity
question.text: Intro
question.infotext:
This first coach will guide you and your company through the first steps in cybersecurity and touches upon various topics. After completing this coach, we will give you more options to dive deeper into some topic areas of your choice.

Some questions have instructions or further information on the right side that are meant to help you in this journey. It is important that you answer the questions honestly in order to get the best results.

Here is a list of all the topics that the coaches will cover:

  • Access Management
  • Asset Management
  • Backup
  • Business Continuity Management
  • Change Management
  • Data Protection/Security
  • Human Resources Security
  • Incident Management
  • Network Security
  • Organisational and Governance
  • Physical and Environmental
  • Risk Management
  • Software Security
  • Supply Chain

question.text: How many employees does your company have?

option.text: I am the only employee
option.comment: Please note that several questions and answers might be worded in a generic way. Think of how to adapt the scenarios to your specific business. Try not to leave out certain questions as they most likely apply to your business as well just in a different way. Note that you are an employee of your own business.

option.text: 1 - 3 employees
option.comment: Please note that several questions and answers might be worded in a generic way. Think of how to adapt the scenarios to your specific business.

option.text: 4 - 9 employees
10 - 19 employees
20 - 50 employees

question.introduction: If you want to improve cybersecurity within your company, it is important that someone takes the responsibility for this journey. This person needs to analyse the current state and implement recommended measures.
question.text: Is someone within your company responsible for cybersecurity?

option.text: Yes
option.comment: Very good, you seem to be aware that cybersecurity is important for your company and that someone should be responsible for this.

option.text: No
option.comment: Without someone responsible for cybersecurity, it is very difficult for your company to get started and constantly improve in this domain. If you are an employee, talk with your manager or superior about this. If you are in a position where you can assign this responsibility to someone, it is highly suggested that you do this immediately.

question.introduction: Whoever is in charge of cybersecurity in your company must have the required power, approval and resources to implement recommended measures. Your company can only improve if concrete steps are taken and are supported by the management team and/or the owners of your company.
question.text: Does the person responsible for cybersecurity have the power and resources to implement cybersecurity measures?

option.text: Yes
No

instruction.text: Without an effort, it is not possible to improve cybersecurity in your company. First and foremost, it is crucial that someone in your company is responsible for actively attending this matter. Second, it would be ideal to allocate resources in a way to consistently and regularly work on the necessary tasks like analysing the current state and implementing recommended measures. At last, the responsible person will need time to deepen, update and extend their cybersecurity knowledge in order to understand recommendations and how to implement them in your company. Depending on your goals, it is best to schedule 2-4 hours per week.

question.introduction: Raising awareness for cybersecurity among your employees is an important factor for preventing cyber incidents. In case an incident occurs nonetheless, trained personnel can act more quickly and adequately to limit the damage as much as possible.
question.text: When did you last conduct a cybersecurity training for your employees?

option.text: Never
More than one year ago
option.comment: Consider doing training regularly (e.g. once per year) to ensure everyone is up-to-date.

option.text: Less than one year ago
option.comment: Very good, keep doing regular training once per year to ensure everyone is up-to-date.

instruction.text:
You can include cybersecurity training as part of the onboarding process to ensure that everyone has received training at least once.

Some topics to include:

  • Cybersecurity threats to your company and in general
  • How to identify/recognise security threats (e.g. phishing mails)
  • Importance of using secure passwords and storing them securely
  • How and where to report incidents
  • How to react correctly in case of an incident
  • Policies of your company and how assets are protected (when applicable)

A basic online training can be found here.

question.text: Does your company define any requirements or rules for handling passwords?

option.text: Yes
No
option.comment: Start by making a short checklist for password security based on the next questions.

instruction.text:
Passwords are widely used to authenticate a user with a system or application. Therefore, everyone in your company needs to know how to handle passwords in a secure manner.

If you don't have any requirements or rules, you can start by making a simple checklist for password security based on the next questions. Here are some points to consider which will be touched upon later:

  • Use strong passwords
  • Do not reuse passwords for different accounts
  • Avoid password/account sharing among employees
  • Change shared credentials in off-boarding process
  • Store passwords safely (e.g. use a password manager to store and generate passwords)
  • Use two-factor authentication (2FA) or multifactor authentication (MFA) whenever possible

question.introduction: Defining strong passwords is crucial to secure your accounts and systems. Have a look at the characteristics of a strong password.
question.text: Do you encourage your employees and yourself to use strong passwords and do you enforce these rules?

option.text: Our rules require strong passwords and we enforce these requirements.
option.comment: This is commendable and very good practice.

option.text: Our rules require strong passwords but we don't enforce these rules.
option.comment: This is good already – as a next step you can start enforcing these rules.

option.text: Users were informed once but we don't have specific rules for strong passwords.
option.comment: Make sure that everyone knows the importance of using secure passwords by informing all your employees. It is time to update your password security checklist to implement the proposed best practices.

option.text: We did not ask users to set strong passwords.
option.comment: Make sure that everyone knows the importance of using secure passwords by informing all your employees. It is time to update your password security checklist to implement the proposed best practices.

instruction.text:
Using strong password for all your accounts is important. Here are characteristics of a strong password:

  • has a minimal length of 12 characters
  • includes upper-case and lower-case characters as well as numbers and symbols
  • contains no data or names of your company or employees
  • doesn't use easy guessable phrases or words available in a dictionary (e.g. admin, password, abc123)
  • avoids simple transformations of words like D00RB377, mypass$
  • doesn't use keyboard paths like asdfghj, uiopjkl

Make sure that this element is on your password security checklist.

Please note that it is better to use strong passwords than to change them regularly.

question.introduction: If one of your passwords get compromised, all the accounts using the same password are at risk. Therefore, every account or system should have its own password.
question.text: Are you using the same passwords for different accounts?

option.text: No, we never reuse passwords.
option.comment: That's very good. Please note that a password manager can help you store all these credentials in a safe way. This topic will be addressed later when we talk specifically about password managers.

option.text: Yes, there are some passwords that are reused.
option.comment: It is only a matter of time until one of your credentials gets compromised. To limit the extent of the damage in such a case, every account should have its own credentials (username and password). A password manager can help you store all these credentials in a safe way. This will be addressed later.

instruction.text:
Every account or system should have its own password to limit damage in case credentials are compromised.


Example of password reuse (not secure):

E-Mail Account:
jdoe@your-company.com | C5Dw-8xZJ-SdkT

Supplier webshop:
jdoe | C5Dw-8xZJ-SdkT


Example with different password for each account (secure):

E-Mail Account:
jdoe@your-company.com | zUnb-BLa8-v5nm

Supplier webshop:
jdoe | kXZS-VjPn9-JuC


Make sure that this element is on your password security checklist.

question.introduction: Sharing credentials for an account among several employees comes with risks (e.g. loss of account ownership). It is best to have a personal account (i.e. one per employee) whenever possible.
question.text: Do several employees use the same credentials (usernames and passwords) to access some accounts or systems?

option.text: Yes
option.comment: Include a step in the off-boarding process, so you don't forget to change all shared passwords the employee has knowledge of.

option.text: No
option.comment: This is very good practice, keep this up.

instruction.text:
It should be avoided that employees use the same accounts. In case this is not possible, you need to change such passwords whenever someone should not have access to the protected resource anymore. To this end, you could, for example, add a step in the off-boarding process that reminds you to set new passwords for reused accounts. To be able to do this, you need a list of all shared accounts.


Example with account sharing for supplier webshop (potentially not secure):

Employee A:
your-company | pLwG-M2dc-22c6

Employee B:
your-company | pLwG-M2dc-22c6


Example with different accounts per employee for supplier webshop (secure):

Employee A:
employee-a | 4RkH-7kyJ-FvJP

Employee B:
employee-b | ZBKP-x9VJ-9uu4


Make sure that this element is on your password security checklist.

question.introduction: For some systems like portals of suppliers or service providers it is not possible to have one account per employee.
question.text: Do you consequently change the passwords for shared accounts as soon as access for one person should be revoked (e.g. when an employee leaves your company)?

option.text: Yes, we change these passwords in these situations or this step just got added to the list of things to do while off-boarding an employee.
No, we don't change these passwords in such a case.
option.comment: Include the step in the off-boarding process so you don't forget to change all shared passwords the employee has knowledge of.

instruction.text:
To limit the risks associated with account shared among multiple employees, it is important to change the password of such accounts as soon as one of the users is no longer authorized to use this account.

Make sure that this element is on your password security checklist.

question.introduction: In today's world, you have a lot of different accounts for various (online) services and purposes.
question.text: How are you keeping track of your credentials?

option.text: We write passwords down on paper (or a different physical place).
option.comment: While at first sight it might seem like a good solution to write your passwords down on paper, ask yourself the following questions: How easy is it for unauthorised persons to gain physical access to the paper? Is there a backup somewhere in case the paper gets lost, stolen or destroyed? Please consider using a password manager instead of paper.

option.text: We store passwords in a spreadsheet or textfile on a computer or mobile phone.
option.comment: Spreadsheets or textfiles are not a secure medium to store credentials. If someone gains access and can read the content of such a file, all the contained passwords are compromised. Please start using a password manager.

option.text: We are using a password manager.
option.comment: Great, a password manager used properly is a good way to store your credentials.

option.text: We don't keep track of our credentials at all.
option.comment: Please consider using a password manager to store your credentials.

option.text: We use a different method than the ones mentioned above.
option.comment: Consider using a password manager if possible.

instruction.text:
When you follow best practices like using strong passwords and not reusing passwords, it becomes impossible for most people to remember all these different credentials. As a consequence, you need to start keeping track of credentials in a secure way.

The best way to do this is to use a password manager that stores your passwords in an encrypted container (for example a file). This way, you just need to remember one strong password which is used to access the securely stored passwords. Additionally, most password managers let you generate secure passwords which helps when you need to set up a new account.

Make sure that this element is on your password security checklist.

question.text: Is the paper (or other physical medium) containing the passwords protected from unauthorised access?

option.text: Yes, it is locked away.
No, it is not protected sufficiently.
option.comment: Please ensure the protection of the medium from unauthorized access.

question.introduction: You should be prepared for when your passwords stored on a physical medium get lost, stolen or destroyed.
question.text: Is there a regularly updated copy of the paper (or other physical medium) containing the passwords?

option.text: Yes, in a different physical location and protected from unauthorised access.
Yes, but in the same location and/or not sufficiently protected against unauthorised access.
option.comment: Make sure to have a copy in a different physical location which is protected against access by unauthorised persons.

option.text: No, there is no regularly updated copy or backup.
option.comment: Make sure to have a copy in a different physical location which is protected against access by unauthorised persons.

instruction.text: It is important to have a copy of the paper or other physical medium containing your passwords in case the original gets lost, stolen or destroyed. This copy should also be protected against access by unauthorised persons. Additionally, the copy should not be in the same physical location as the original. Note that taking a photograph with your smartphone is not a good idea as it can potentially expose your passwords.

question.text: Is there a solid reason why you cannot or do not want to use a password manager?

option.text: Yes, I really cannot use a password manager and I am sure of this.
Yes, I really do not want to use a password manager and I am sure of this.
No, there is not really something stopping me from using a password manager.
option.comment: Don't wait any longer and start using a password manager then.

option.text: I do not know.
option.comment: Then there seems not to be a reason against starting to use a password manager.

question.introduction: It is much more secure to use a password management solution that does not store your passwords in the cloud or on servers out of your control.
question.text: Are you using a cloud-based password management software which stores your passwords online?

option.text: No, we don't use a cloud-based solution.
Yes, we are using a cloud-based solution.
option.comment: Consider switching to an application where you know that the data is not stored in the cloud or on servers out of your control. Also, make sure that you can access your passwords in case the Internet or cloud service is not available or off-line.

option.text: I don't know.
option.comment: Consult the documentation of your password management solution and consider switching to an application where you know that the data is not stored in the cloud or on servers out of your control. Also, make sure that you can access your passwords in case the Internet or cloud service is not available or off-line.

instruction.text:
It is much more secure to use a password management solution that does not store your passwords in the cloud or on servers out of your control. On the one hand, the data might not be available to you in case the Internet is not working (if there is no offline-access feature). On the other hand, a data breach could expose your credentials – remember that such services are a worthwhile target for cyber criminals. Try to avoid password manager solutions that allow to manage and view your credentials in a browser (web application).

Example software that meets this criteria:
KeePass2 (Windows), Strongbox (iOS, macOS), KeePassX (macOS, Linux), KeePass2Android (Android)

You can synchronize the encrypted archive of your password manager's data with a cloud service to keep everything updated on multiple devices. If you use synchronisation, don't forget to still keep backups which are separate and not automatically overwritten.

question.introduction: A copy of important data which is stored elsewhere is called a backup.
question.text: Did you ever make a backup of the data on the «important data» list (see instruction)?

option.text: No, I never made a copy of any data.
option.comment: Do not wait any longer and start doing regular backups of all your important data.

option.text: Yes, I did a copy of some of this data at least once already.
option.comment: That's a good start. Look that you can do regular backups of all your important data.

option.text: Yes, I did a copy of all the important data multiple times already.
option.comment: Great. Make sure you keep doing regular backups of all your important data.

instruction.text:
Backups can be used to restore the data if desired, for example in case of data loss, accidental deletion or corruption. In case of a ransomware attack, having a backup is essential to recover your data. It is important that you identify what data is important to your company in order to determine whether it is worth saving. This heavily depends on your business but here are some examples:

  • list of customers and suppliers
  • personnel records
  • administration documents
  • contracts and insurance policies
  • business plans and marketing material
  • credentials (usernames and passwords)
  • software licenses
  • financial data
  • payment recipes and account statements
  • tax-related documents
  • inventory records

Make an accurate list of all important data your company has stored. Also write down precisely where this data is stored.

Please note that replication/synchronisation is not the same as a backup because replicated/synchronised data is updated continuously. This means that most likely there is no history of the data. Consequently, it might not be possible to restore deleted files. In contrast, a backup is a basically the state of the data at a certain point in time and can be recovered.

question.introduction: You should back up your data at least once every week. The more often you do this, the fewer data can get lost.
question.text: How often do you back up your important data?

option.text: Every day.
Minimum once per week.
option.comment: Ask yourself if you might want to do a backup every day.

option.text: Minimum once per month.
option.comment: Try to increase the frequency in case you determine that you would lose too much data in case of an incident. It is recommended that you back up your data at the very least once every week.

option.text: Minimum once per year.
option.comment: It is recommended that you back up your data at least once every week.

option.text: Less often than once per year.
option.comment: It is recommended that you back up your data at least once every week.

instruction.text:
Depending on the type of your business, important data may change more or less frequently. It is essential that you ask yourself what amount of data are you willing to lose in case of an incident. The answer to this question will guide you towards the optimal frequency of your backup solution.

It is recommended that you back up your data at the very least once every week. Depending on your business and the type of data you are storing, you might want to back up more frequently.

Amend each item on your list of important data with the amount of time you are willing to lose the data for the respective item. Change your backup plans in order to satisfy your requirements.

question.text: Does your backup run automatically?

option.text: No, we manually back up our data.
option.comment: Consider automating your backup processes.

option.text: Yes, but there are some exceptions.
Yes, all backup processes run automatically.

instruction.text:
Try to automate your backups, so you do not need to do it this manually. On the one hand, this saves you time that can be invested to further improve cybersecurity at your company. On the other hand, it assures that the backups are not accidentally forgotten.

It is important to check regularly if the backups are actually being made according to the set schedule.

question.introduction: Having one backup is not enough to protect you reliably from losing your data.
question.text: Do you have multiple copies of your backups?

option.text: No
Yes, but they are all in the same physical location.
Yes, in different physical locations.

instruction.text:
It could be that your primary backup gets compromised and will no longer be usable. There could be many reasons for this, such as theft of both, the backup and the original data, environmental hazards affecting both systems or malicious activity.

Therefore, you should have at least two backups in different physical locations. For example, the second copy could be stored encrypted in a cloud-based service. For very small businesses, the second copy could just be taken home by the owner and rotated once per week.

Don't forget to properly secure external storage drives with encryption and by physically locking them away appropriately.

question.text: Do you have at least one regularly updated copy of your password manager's data in a different physical location?

option.text: Yes
No
option.comment: Make sure that you can still access your passwords in case your computer does not work, gets stolen or lost.

instruction.text:
Having a separate copy of your password manager's data is important in case your computer does not work, gets stolen or lost.

Please note that synchronisation with a cloud service might not offer sufficient protection from accidental or malicious updates to the data. In particular, a synced cloud drive does not protect against ransomware attacks. It is recommended that the copy of your data is preserved at regular intervals (e.g. snapshots) which can be restored if necessary.

question.introduction: Your company should be able to still function to a certain extent in case a key system (e.g. internet connection, computer, server, printer, production machine) fails.
question.text: Do you have contingency plans for your key systems in case of failure?

option.text: Yes, we have informal (thought out) contingency plans
option.comment: Very good, you are better prepared with contingency plans and can act quicker. Try to write these plans down.

option.text: Yes, we have formal (written down) contingency plans
option.comment: Very good, you are better prepared with contingency plans and can act quicker.

option.text: No, we don't have such plans
option.comment: Being prepared in case a system fails is important for your company's continued operation. Make informal (thought out) or formal (written down) contingency plans.

instruction.text:
Ask yourself what you would do in case an important/vital system fails. Having a contingency plan which can be informally thought out or formally written down helps you to get a head start in such a situation.

Make a list of the key systems your company is relying upon for daily operation. For each system, try to find alternatives or plan what you are going to do in case of failure.

question.introduction: One of the first steps in knowing your environment is to make a list of all Information and Communication Technology (ICT) assets in your company.
question.text: Do you have an inventory of ICT assets (all hardware assets that store or process information whether connected to a network or not)?

option.text: Yes, it is complete and detailed enough
option.comment: That is very good, this will help you later to implement other measures.

option.text: Yes, but it is not complete or not detailed enough
option.comment: Try to make the inventory of ICT assets complete and detailed since you will need it later.

option.text: No, we don't have such an inventory
option.comment: Make a complete and detailed inventory of all ICT assets in your company.

instruction.text:
Make a list of all ICT assets that are owned by your company. If private devices are also used for your business (bring-your-own-device), include them as well.

Your list should entail all hardware that stores or processes information, for example:

  • computers and laptops
  • mobile phones and tablets
  • switches, routers and modems
  • servers
  • printers
  • storage devices
  • ...

You will need this list later to know where you should implement security measures for your ITC hardware.

question.introduction: The software that runs on the devices is as important as the hardware itself.
question.text: Do you have an inventory of all software platforms and applications in use as well as all your licenses?

option.text: Yes, we have a complete inventory.
option.comment: That is very good and will help you later.

option.text: Yes, but only partially complete.
option.comment: Your next step is to make the software inventory complete and detailed since you need it later.

option.text: No, we don't have such an inventory.
option.comment: Make a complete and detailed software inventory.

instruction.text:
Make a list of all the platforms, software and applications your business uses to operate or depends on. Also, include all licenses that you need for using these systems.

You will need this list later to know where you should implement security measures for your software assets.

question.introduction: Some ICT assets and software are more important to your business than others.
question.text: Are your resources/assets in the inventories prioritized according to their criticality?

option.text: Yes, we assigned a criticality to the items in our hardware and software inventories.
No, we did not assign criticality to our assets.
option.comment: Think about which resources/assets are important to your company and then assign criticality to your hardware and software inventories.

instruction.text:
Knowing what ICT assets and software are vital to your business is necessary to prioritise your cybersecurity efforts. Think about which resources/assets are important to your company and then assign criticality to your hardware and software inventories.

If you have limited resources to protect and secure your systems, start with the one that has a high priority.

question.introduction: Most devices (e.g. routers, wireless access points, ...) and some software get shipped with default passwords.
question.text: Did you change the default passwords of software and devices?

option.text: Yes, all default passwords are changed
option.comment: Very good. Remember to change the default passwords of devices that you will buy in the future.

option.text: Some are changed but others are not
option.comment: Set up a task to change the remaining default passwords and then remember to do this when you buy new devices in the future.

option.text: I'm not sure
option.comment: Just to be safe, set up a task to change all currently used default passwords and then remember to do this when you buy new devices in the future.

option.text: No, they are not changed
option.comment: Set up a task to change all currently used default passwords and then remember to do this when you buy new devices in the future.

instruction.text:
Most devices and some software get shipped with default passwords that are commonly known and well-documented. This poses a risk if you do not change them since a malicious actor could easily log in with these default credentials.

It is also possible that the vendor or the software generates a secure one-time password for the device or system. Such a randomly generated password does not necessarily need to be changed if you know that it is unique and specifically generated for your device or system.

question.text: Do you revoke user accounts and permissions to internal and external systems while off-boarding an employee?

option.text: Yes, we immediately revoke all credentials
option.comment: Great. Don't forget to keep the list of affected applications/systems up-to-date at all times.

option.text: Yes, we revoke the credentials within a month after an employee leaves
option.comment: Try to revoke all credentials immediately while off-boarding an employee. Don't forget to keep the list of affected applications/systems up-to-date at all times.

option.text: I'm not sure what user accounts or credentials to revoke.
option.comment: Make sure you have a list of applications/systems where your employees have accounts and keep this list up-to-date at all times. If an employee leaves, consult this list and revoke access to all applications/systems immediately during off-boarding.

option.text: No, we don't strictly revoke access while off-boarding
option.comment: If an employee leaves revoke access to all applications/systems immediately during off-boarding. Make sure you have a list of applications/systems where your employees have accounts and keep this list up-to-date at all times.

instruction.text:
When an employee is leaving your company, it is important that they no longer have access to systems and accounts of your company. Therefore, it is crucial to revoke all credentials while off-boarding the employee. This is even more important in case of an immediate dismissal.

An list of applications/systems that is up-to-date helps to keep track of internal and external accounts that your employees have access to.

question.introduction: Should a cyber incident occur, you need to be able to take appropriate measures and know who is responsible and can make decisions on how to respond.
question.text: Are the responsible persons and contact persons in case of an IT incident defined and available?

option.text: Yes
option.comment: This is very good. Don't forget to periodically check if the contact information is up-to-date and whether the responsible persons are available.

option.text: No
option.comment: Make sure that the responsible persons and contact persons in case of an IT incident are defined and available.

instruction.text:
In case of a cybersecurity incident, you need to make decisions and respond with appropriate measures. Therefore, you need to define who is responsible to handle incidents like this and who needs to be contacted.

It is recommended that at least one of the responsible persons holds a managing position (or is a company owner) since the decisions to be made are of high importance and relevance to the company.

Print this list of persons including all contact information in order to have this always accessible.

question.introduction: Apart from internal communication channels, you need the contact details of important third-parties as well.
question.text: Do you have contact information of the following relevant third-parties assembled and maintained?

option.text: Law enforcement
Government departments
Vendors
Suppliers
Others

instruction.text:
In case of a cyber incident, a list of important external or third-party contacts comes in handy. This includes emergency numbers and otherwise relevant contacts. Here are some examples:

  • Law enforcement (e.g. police)
  • Government departments
  • Important vendors and suppliers
  • IT consultancy
  • Internet provider
  • ...

Print this list in order to have it always accessible.

question.introduction: Knowing on what external services your company depends on is important.
question.text: Are external ICT systems which are relevant to your organisation or on which your organisation depends on catalogued?

option.text: Yes, we know which external systems are relevant
option.comment: Plan what you would do in case a system which is relevant to your company fails.

option.text: No, we don't know this
option.comment: Make a list of all external ICT services that your business depends on or relies on. You need to plan ahead what to do in case such a system fails.

instruction.text:
You need to be ready if an essential external system that you rely or depend on is not available or compromised. To know how you can be prepared for such a scenario, the relevant external services need to be known.

Make a list of all external ICT systems (e.g. Microsoft 365, Dropbox, hosting provider, e-mail service) that your business depends on or relies on. Then plan what you would do in case such a system fails.

question.text: Does your business have a wireless network (WLAN)?

option.text: Yes, we have a wireless network
No, we don't have a wireless network

question.introduction: Using an unencrypted wireless network with no password to access company-resources is insecure.
question.text: Are your corporate wireless networks encrypted and protected with a password?

option.text: Yes, they are protected with a secure password or passphrase
Yes, every employee uses their own credentials for accessing wireless networks
No, there is no password required

instruction.text:
Protecting your company's wireless network with a secure password or passphrase is important to stop unwanted actors from accessing your internal resources. This password should not be easily guessed and generally follow the same characteristics of a strong password as seen earlier (consult the password checklist that you created). This is important since weak password can be cracked using a brute-force attack.

Set up WPA3 or WPA2 security whenever possible. Either using a pre-shared key (PSK) or in 802.1X mode with a RADIUS server (more complicated setup for larger businesses). Avoid the vulnerable WEP standard as it is fundamentally broken. Also note that just hiding your network by not broadcasting your network name (SSID) does not sufficiently protect you at all.

Consult the documentation of your router or wireless access point if you don't know how to set up encryption for your wireless network.

question.introduction: Offering a WLAN for guests is often considered a courtesy but can pose a risk to your network of company-internal devices.
question.text: Can guests use a wireless network that you operate?

option.text: Yes
No

question.introduction: Splitting your network into multiple zones is called network segmentation.
question.text: Is the wireless network for guests separated from your corporate wireless network?

option.text: Yes
No
option.comment: Temporarily stop offering a guest network and look into separating the guest network from your company-internal network. Give the guest network a different passphrase.

option.text: We will no longer offer a guest WLAN

instruction.text:
Having a completely separate wireless network for guests with direct access to the Internet and no access to company-resources is a basic example for network segmentation. It reduces the attack surface and system vulnerability, and keeps unknown devices out of your company-internal network.

If you operate a wireless network for guests, you should separate this network and give the guest network a different passphrase. Another option is to temporarily (until you have separated the networks) or permanently stop offering a WLAN for your guests.

question.introduction: Depending on the type of your business, physical security is an important factor.
question.text: Are your work areas where you store sensitive/important data separated from the public?

option.text: We don't have any separation.
option.comment: Without separation, it is very easy for a malicious actor to steal, alter or erase your important data. Consider restricting physical access or locking sensitive/important data away.

option.text: The zones are somehow divided but can be accessed easily.
option.comment: If these zones can be accessed easily, it is also easy for a malicious actor to steal, alter or erase your important data. Consider restricting physical access or locking sensitive/important data away.

option.text: We don't have any separation but all sensitive/important data is locked away.
option.comment: Additionally, try to separate the work areas where you store sensitive/important data to increase security.

option.text: The zones are somehow divided but can be accessed easily. All sensitive/important data is locked away.
option.comment: Additionally, try to separate the work areas where you store sensitive/important data to increase security.

option.text: The zones are separated by physical means (e.g. a locked door) and cannot be accessed easily.

instruction.text:
Customers should generally not have access to sensitive areas of your company. For example, this can be rooms or areas where you store customer data, schedules, personal information, company secrets, valuables, business documents, contracts, etc.

Rooms like server rooms or archives need increased protection and should not be accessible by customers.

As an alternative, in case you cannot separate the zones, you can keep all important/sensitive data locked away at all times.

question.text: Do you have servers or other critical IT infrastructure in your office or at your company's location?

option.text: Yes
No

question.introduction: It is important to keep the most important parts of your IT infrastructure particularly safe.
question.text: Is physical access to your critical IT infrastructure (e.g. servers) protected against access by unauthorized individuals?

option.text: Yes, access is limited to authorized individuals and there is physical protection.
Yes partially, access is limited to authorized individuals but there is no physical protection.
option.comment: Additionally, try to add physical protection.

option.text: Yes partially, there is physical protection but access is not limited to authorized individuals.
option.comment: Additionally, try limit access to a few authorized persons only.

option.text: No, access is not sufficiently protected or limited.

instruction.text: Servers, backup medias, data storage, etc. are important parts of your IT infrastructure and need to be kept particularly safe because a compromise of these parts would have a great impact on your business. Only authorize as few employees as possible for such areas and physically restrict access, e.g. by a locked door or cabinet.

question.introduction: Managing risk is important for businesses of all sizes and in all sectors.
question.text: Is someone formally responsible for risk management?

option.text: Yes
option.comment: Very good that someone is formally responsible for risk management. Don't forget that sufficient resources should be allocated to keep the risk management up-to-date and aligned with your business.

option.text: No
option.comment: Risk management is a crucial factor in sustaining your company long-term. Someone should be made responsible for this as soon as possible and sufficient resources should be allocated to this person.

instruction.text: Someone needs to be explicitly responsible for risk management. In smaller companies this can also be the owner itself. Risk management is so important since the likelihood and severity of potential risks can be reduced drastically by identifying them early and taking appropriate measures against them.

question.introduction: Malware is widespread and without protection it is just a matter of time until your company will be affected.
question.text: Is malware protection (e.g. antivirus program) active on all computers, laptops and mobile devices?

option.text: No, malware protection is not installed.
option.comment: Malware protection is very important and should be installed on all devices as soon as possible.

option.text: Partially, malware protection is only installed on some devices.
option.comment: Malware protection is very important and should be installed on all computers, laptops and mobile devices as soon as possible.

option.text: Yes, malware protection is installed on all devices.
option.comment: Very good. Make sure that the malware protection is actually active on all systems.

option.text: Generally yes, but there are a few exceptions.
option.comment: Consider installing malware protection on all devices so that there are no exceptions anymore.

instruction.text:
Malware is malicious software that can infect your computer or mobile device. Some types of malware are viruses, spyware, worms or trojans. This type of software can cause significant harm to your computers, your data and the other devices in your network.

Protection against malware is absolutely essential and should be installed on all computers, laptops and mobile devices.

You can consult the list of IT assets that you created earlier and check all devices.

question.text: Is there a solid reason why you don't want to or cannot install malware protection on the few exceptions referred to in the previous question?

option.text: Yes, I am sure of this.
No, there is not really something stopping me from installing malware protection everywhere.
option.comment: Don't wait any longer and install malware protection then.

option.text: I do not know.
option.comment: Then there seems not to be a reason against install malware protection.

question.introduction: So called «signatures» are used to identify malware on your devices. Since malware is constantly changing, you need to have up-to-date signatures to detect the most recent malicious payloads.
question.text: Are malware signatures updated on a regular basis?

option.text: Yes, this is done automatically.
Yes, this is a scheduled task.
option.comment: Try to automate updates of the signatures if possible.

option.text: No, signatues are not regularly updated.
option.comment: Look into how to update the signatures of your anti-malware solution, either automatically or with a scheduled task.

instruction.text: Your malware protection should always have up-to-date malware signatures in order to detect new and evolving malicious software. Updating of signatures can be done automatically with most solutions but can also be a scheduled manual task.

question.introduction: Software updates allow patching security vulnerabilities or can introduce new features.
question.text: Are devices, software and systems updated regularly (manually or automatically)?

option.text: Yes, all systems are updated regularly
Yes, most systems are updated regularly
option.comment: Try to update all devices, software and systems to benefit from the latest security fixes.

option.text: No, many systems are not updated regularly
option.comment: Start updating all your devices, software and systems since is important to get the latest security fixes.

option.text: No, software or devices are not regularly updated
option.comment: Start updating your devices, software and systems since is important to get the latest security fixes.

instruction.text:
You should always try to keep your systems and software on the latest available version. Having the most recent patches for known vulnerabilities installed means that your devices, software and systems are better protected against cyberattacks. If you cannot let updates install automatically, set up a scheduled task to do so in regular intervals.

You can consult the list of IT assets and the list of software that you created earlier to know what needs regular updates.

question.introduction: Automatic updates are an easy way to keep your systems up-to-date without manual intervention.
question.text: Are automatic updates activated on your systems?

option.text: Yes, on all systems
Yes, but there are exceptions
option.comment: Try to activate automatic updates on all your systems.

option.text: No, automatic updates are not activated
option.comment: Activate automatic updates on all your systems, so you don't need to manually install them.

instruction.text:
To ease the time it takes to update your systems, most software and devices can be configured to install updates automatically. This is an easy way to keep your systems up-to-date with the latest security fixes without manual intervention.

Consult the documentation or manual of your systems to find out whether automatic updates are offered and how to enable them.

question.introduction: Unauthorized persons should not be able to use an unlocked computer.
question.text: Are user sessions on computers and mobile devices automatically locked after a standard period of inactivity?

option.text: Yes, the systems lock after less than 5 minutes
Yes, the systems lock after more than 5 Minutes
option.comment: Adjust the settings to automatically lock the systems after 5 minutes or less.

option.text: Generally yes, the systems lock after less than 5 minutes but there are some exceptions
option.comment: Make sure that the exempted systems are protected sufficiently and do not allow access to sensitive information or resources.

option.text: Generally yes, the systems lock after more than 5 minutes but there are some exceptions
option.comment: Adjust the settings to automatically lock the systems after 5 minutes or less. Make sure that the exempted systems are protected sufficiently and do not allow access to sensitive information or resources.

option.text: No, we don't automatically lock our systems
option.comment: Update the settings of your systems to automatically lock systems of your company after a period of inactivity of 5 minutes or less.

instruction.text:
Generally, users should always lock systems when they are leaving the system unattended. Locking your computers after a period of inactivity can prevent others from using the logged in account in case the last user forgot to lock or log off the workstation. Note that just showing a screensaver that can be stopped without providing a password or PIN is not considered secure.

Most operating systems (Windows, macOS, Linux, ...) can be configured to lock when the session is inactive for some minutes. Even mobile devices like smartphones or tables (iOS, Android, ...) have this feature. Consult the documentation or manual of your systems to find out more.

There might be some systems where it is not possible to enforce this rule. In these cases, make sure that the unattended system does not allow access to sensitive information or other systems/resources you want to have protected.

dictionary.entry: Make someone responsible
Designate a person responsible for cybersecurity in your company to get started on this journey.
Empower the responsible person
Enable the person responsible for cybersecurity to do their job properly. This means to assign the necessary resources available and grant them the power to implement measures.
Employee Training
Train your employees (and yourself) in the basics as laid out in the referenced question of the coach.
Password Security Checklist
Create a password security checklist and add the elements which are discussed in the coach to create basic guidelines for your company.
Use strong passwords

Inform all employees to set strong passwords as outlined in the question and add this element to your password guidelines. Creating strong passwords is one of the easiest ways to guard against cybercrime.
No password reuse
Change all passwords that are reused to limit damages in case credentials get compromised.
Change shared passwords when off-boarding employees
Change all shared passwords after someone has their access revoked in order to ensure they no longer know the active credentials. Add this step to your off-boarding process.
Make backups
Make regular backups of all your important data and store it in a different physical location.
Make regular backups
Make regular backups of all your important data and store it in a different physical location. It is recommended that you back up your data at least once every week.
Multiple backups
Make at least two backups and store one of them in a physical location which is different from the other backups or the actual data being backed up.
Backups in different physical locations
Store at least one of your backups in physical location which is different from the other backups or the actual data being backed up.
Make contingency plans
Make informal (thought out) or formal (written down) contingency plans in case a system fails so your company can continue to operate to a certain extent.
Make ITC asset inventory
Make a list/inventory of all ICT assets in your company (all hardware assets that store or process information whether connected to a network or not).
Make software inventory
Make a list/inventory of all software, platforms and applications in your company including all licenses.
Change default passwords
Change all currently used default passwords of all your software and devices.
Change default passwords

If an employee leaves revoke access to all applications/systems immediately during off-boarding. Make sure you have a list of applications/systems where your employees have accounts and keep this list up-to-date at all times.
Responsible persons in case of an incident
Define the responsible persons to make decisions and define contact persons in case of an IT incident. Also, make sure they are available.
Contact information of third-parties
Assemble and maintain a list with contact information of relevant third-parties.
Catalogue external ITC services
Make a list of all external ICT services that your business depends on or relies on. You need to plan ahead what to do in case such a system fails.
Set a WLAN password
Protect your wireless network with a secure password/passphrase to stop other people from accessing it.
Separate guest WLAN
Separate the guest WLAN from your company-internal WLAN or stop offering this service for your guests.
Restrict physical access
Consider restricting physical access for customers to areas where you store important/sensitive data. If you cannot do this, you should keep this data locked away at all times.
Protect critical IT infrastructure
Physically protect your critical IT infrastructure (e.g. servers) from unauthorized access and limit the amount of employees that are authorized.
Make someone responsible for risk management
Someone should be made responsible for risk management and sufficient resources should be allocated to this person. This is a crucial factor in sustaining your company long-term.
Update malware signatures regularly
Update the signatures of your anti-malware solution regularly. This can be done automatically with most solutions or manually as a regularly scheduled task.
Install software updates
Start installing updates on all your devices, software and systems. This is very important to get the latest security fixes.
Install software updates
Update the settings of your systms to automatically lock systems of your company after a period of inactivity of 5 minutes or less.
Use a password manager
Start using a password manager to keep track of your credentials. Check the recommended software on the linked question.
Install malware protection
Install malware protection (e.g. antivirus program) on all computers and laptops and make sure it is active.
